claim_reports.claim_text: It can take a plastic bottle 1,000 years to decompose in a landfill.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence presents a mixed view on the decomposition time of plastic bottles. A high-reliability source states that plastic bottles take about 450 years to decompose, refuting the claim of 1,000 years. However, two medium-reliability sources indicate that decomposition can take between 450 to 1,000 years, supporting the claim. Additionally, a high-reliability source suggests that plastic may take more than 1,000 years, adding further complexity to the claim.

refutes.title: [PDF] How Long Does It Take Garbage to Decompose?
refutes.evidence_summary: The evidence states that plastic bottles take 450 years to decompose, which contradicts the claim that it takes 1,000 years.
refutes.snippet: But plastic bags we use in our everyday life take 10-20 years to decompose, while plastic bottles take 450 years.

supports.title: How Long Does It Really Take for Plastics to Biodegrade?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that plastic bottles can take between 450 to 1,000 years to decompose in a landfill, which supports the claim that it can take a plastic bottle 1,000 years to decompose.
supports.snippet: Plastic bottles (PET): 450–1,000 years ; Plastic bags (PE/HDPE): 500–1,000 years ; Polystyrene products: 500+ years.

supports.title: How long does it take for plastic to biodegrade?
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that traditional plastic can take hundreds of years to decompose, which supports the claim that a plastic bottle can take a long time to decompose in a landfill, potentially up to 1,000 years.
supports.snippet: Biodegradable plastics take only three to six months to fully decompose, far quicker than traditional plastic that can take hundreds of years.

unclear.title: The impact of plastic on climate change | Environmental Center
unclear.evidence_summary: It takes more than 1,000 years for plastic to decompose. Every plastic bottle, straw and container ever thrown away is still intact and ...
unclear.snippet: It takes more than 1,000 years for plastic to decompose. Every plastic bottle, straw and container ever thrown away is still intact and ...

claim_reports.claim_text: Most plastics do not biodegrade and break down into microplastics.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence from multiple high-reliability sources consistently indicates that most plastics do not biodegrade effectively and instead break down into microplastics, which are harmful to the environment and marine life.

supports.title: From plastics to microplastics and organisms - PMC - PubMed Central
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses how plastics do not biodegrade readily and instead break down into smaller pieces, known as microplastics, which can be consumed by marine organisms. This supports the claim that most plastics do not biodegrade and instead break down into microplastics.
supports.snippet: Plastics are not readily degradable and its biodegradation in natural water bodies takes several years. The process by which plastics biodegrade in the marine ...

supports.title: Say hello to biodegradable microplastics | University of California
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses how plastics break down into smaller pieces, ultimately becoming microplastics, which are harmful to marine life. This supports the claim that most plastics do not biodegrade but instead fragment into microplastics.
supports.snippet: New research from scientists at the University of California San Diego and materials-science company Algenesis shows that their plant-based polymers biodegrade.

supports.title: The plastic crisis: What's the big deal with microplastics?
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses how plastics do not biodegrade but instead break down into smaller pieces due to environmental factors, ultimately forming microplastics that can be ingested by marine life.
supports.snippet: Plastic waste does not biodegrade, rather, it breaks down, fragmented by wind, waves, and sunlight into ever-smaller pieces. The two main ...

supports.title: Biological Degradation of Plastics and Microplastics - NIH
supports.evidence_summary: The article discusses the persistence of plastics in the environment, indicating that they can remain for hundreds of years and break down into microplastics, which aligns with the claim that most plastics do not biodegrade effectively.
supports.snippet: Biodegradation may effectively reduce the harm of additives to plastics and achieve a better ecological environment [13]. Plastics likely have a ...

supports.title: Biodegradation of macro- and micro-plastics in environment
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that plastic pollution is persistent in the environment, taking hundreds to thousands of years to decompose, and that plastics can fragment into microplastics, which are pervasive in ecosystems.
supports.snippet: The steps involved in the biodegradation of plastics are film formation, deterioration, fragmentation, assimilation, and mineralization.

supports.title: Plastic planet: How tiny plastic particles are polluting our soil - UNEP
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that plastics are persistent in the environment, taking between 100 to 1,000 years to decompose, and they fragment into microplastics, which are found in every ecosystem.
supports.snippet: Much of it ends up in landfills, where it may take up to 1,000 years to degrade, leaching potentially toxic substances into the soil and water.

claim_reports.claim_text: Plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers. Multiple high-reliability sources, including the EIA and Live Science, confirm that plastics are derived from hydrocarbons from oil and natural gas, which are processed into monomers like ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid.

supports.title: How much oil is used to make plastic? - EIA
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that plastics are produced from natural gas and crude oil feedstocks, which are processed to create the basic building blocks for plastics, indicating that oil and gas molecules are indeed chemically bonded to create monomers used in plastic production.
supports.snippet: Plastics are produced from natural gas, feedstocks derived from natural gas processing, and feedstocks derived from crude oil refining. The U.S. Energy ...

supports.title: How do we turn oil into plastic? - Live Science
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that plastics are produced from hydrocarbons derived from oil and natural gas, which are broken down into their component parts to create monomers, supporting the claim about the chemical bonding of oil and gas molecules.
supports.snippet: Plastic that's synthesized from oil and natural gas is made by isolating hydrocarbons, breaking them down into their component parts and then ...

supports.title: How Are Plastic Bottles Made? : O.Berk Company
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that plastics, including plastic bottles, are made from petrochemical feedstocks derived from crude oil and natural gas, which are processed to create monomers like ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid. This supports the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
supports.snippet: It is a polymer primarily derived from petroleum hydrocarbons and is the result of a reaction between monomers ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid. In the ...

supports.title: How Are Plastic Bottles Made? | The Cary Company
supports.evidence_summary: The article explains that plastic bottles are made from polyethylene terephthalate (PET), which is produced by chemically combining two monomers derived from crude oil, specifically monoethylene glycol (MEG) and dimethyl terephthalate (DMT). This process confirms the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
supports.snippet: The Bottle-Making Process · 1. Plastic Resin Preparation & Melting · 2. Bottle Forming Methods · 3. Cooling & Trimming · 4. The Inspection Process.

supports.title: How Plastics Are Made - Manufacturing - BioProcess International
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that plastic bottles are made from polyethylene terephthalate (PET), which is produced by chemically combining two monomers derived from oil and natural gas, thus supporting the claim that plastic bottles are made by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules to create monomers.
supports.snippet: ... monomers used to make plastics have been derived from oil and natural gas. In fact, many monomers were originally by products of oil and natural gas processing.

supports.title: How plastics are made - Plastics Europe
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence explains that plastic bottles are made from crude oil, which is refined into naphtha, and then chemically combined with specific monomers to create polyethylene terephthalate (PET). This process involves bonding oil and gas molecules to form the necessary monomers, supporting the claim.
supports.snippet: Plastics are made from natural materials such as cellulose, coal, natural gas, salt and crude oil through a polymerisation or polycondensation process.

claim_reports.claim_text: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch traps millions of pieces of plastic debris.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: Multiple high-reliability sources confirm that the Great Pacific Garbage Patch contains millions of pieces of plastic debris, primarily in the form of microplastics, trapped by ocean currents.

supports.title: Garbage Patches - Marine Debris Program - NOAA
supports.evidence_summary: The article confirms that the Great Pacific Garbage Patch contains a significant amount of plastic debris, including millions of pieces, particularly in the form of microplastics, which are prevalent by count.
supports.snippet: The debris ranges in size, from large abandoned fishing nets to tiny microplastics, which are plastic pieces smaller than 5mm in size. This ...

supports.title: TRASH TALK: What is the Great Pacific Garbage Patch?
supports.evidence_summary: The article confirms that the Great Pacific Garbage Patch is a collection of marine debris, primarily composed of tiny plastic pieces known as microplastics, which are trapped in the gyre's stable center.
supports.snippet: A garbage patch is made up of tiny plastic pieces called “microplastics” that are less than 5 millimeters long. It's more like pepper flakes swirling in a ...

supports.title: Evidence that the Great Pacific Garbage Patch is rapidly ... - Nature
supports.evidence_summary: The article confirms that the Great Pacific Garbage Patch contains millions of pieces of plastic debris, primarily in the form of microplastics, which account for a significant portion of the total debris in the area.
supports.snippet: Microplastics accounted for 8% of the total mass but 94% of the estimated 1.8 (1.1–3.6) trillion pieces floating in the area. Plastic collected ...

supports.title: Most plastic in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch comes from the ...
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence indicates that the Great Pacific Garbage Patch is a significant accumulation of marine debris, primarily composed of plastic, which is trapped by the ocean currents of the North Pacific Subtropical Gyre.
supports.snippet: More than three-quarters of floating plastic debris comes from fishing activities.

unclear.title: Great Pacific Garbage Patch - National Geographic Education
unclear.evidence_summary: The amount of debris in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch accumulates because much of it is not biodegradable. Many plastics, for instance, do not ...
unclear.snippet: The amount of debris in the Great Pacific Garbage Patch accumulates because much of it is not biodegradable. Many plastics, for instance, do not ...

claim_reports.claim_text: There are five plastic-filled gyres in the world's seas.
claim_reports.verdict_summary: The evidence strongly supports the claim that there are five plastic-filled gyres in the world's seas, as confirmed by multiple high-reliability sources including NOAA and Global Citizen, which detail the existence of these gyres across different oceanic regions.

supports.title: Garbage Patches - Marine Debris Program - NOAA
supports.evidence_summary: The source confirms that there are five gyres in the ocean, which are areas where garbage patches form due to ocean currents. It specifically states that these gyres include one in the Indian Ocean, two in the Atlantic Ocean, and two in the Pacific Ocean, thus supporting the claim about the existence of five plastic-filled gyres.
supports.snippet: There are five gyres in the ocean. One in the Indian Ocean, two in the Atlantic Ocean, and two in the Pacific Ocean. Garbage patches of ...

supports.title: There's Not Just 1 Great Oceanic Garbage Patch — There Are 5
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that there are five gyres in the ocean, which are responsible for forming garbage patches, thus supporting the claim that there are five plastic-filled gyres in the world's seas.
supports.snippet: The biggest of these gyres, and the biggest ecosystem in the world, is the Northern Pacific Gyre, which hosts the Great Pacific Garbage Patch.

supports.title: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch - The Ocean Cleanup
supports.evidence_summary: The evidence confirms that there are five gyres in the world's oceans, each containing garbage patches formed by marine debris. This supports the claim that there are five plastic-filled gyres in the seas.
supports.snippet: The Great Pacific Garbage Patch (GPGP) is the largest of the five offshore plastic accumulation zones in the world's oceans. It is located halfway between ...

unclear.title: Global map shows where ocean plastics pose greatest threats - News
unclear.evidence_summary: High-risk zones include the mid-latitude North Pacific and North Atlantic oceans, parts of the North Indian Ocean and coastal East Asia.
unclear.snippet: High-risk zones include the mid-latitude North Pacific and North Atlantic oceans, parts of the North Indian Ocean and coastal East Asia.

unclear.title: Tracking Ocean Plastic From Space | NASA Earthdata
unclear.evidence_summary: About 8 million tons of plastic flow from rivers and beaches into the ocean every year. These plastics are carried by ocean currents and broken ...
unclear.snippet: About 8 million tons of plastic flow from rivers and beaches into the ocean every year. These plastics are carried by ocean currents and broken ...

unclear.title: Where does the plastic in our oceans come from? - Our World in Data
unclear.evidence_summary: More than one-third of ocean plastic inputs come from the Philippines. The distribution of plastic inputs is reflected on the world map.
unclear.snippet: More than one-third of ocean plastic inputs come from the Philippines. The distribution of plastic inputs is reflected on the world map.

transcript_data.text: This is the story of three plastic bottles, empty and discarded. Their journeys are about to diverge with outcomes that impact nothing less than the fate of the planet. But they weren't always this way. To understand where these bottles end up, we must first explore their origins. The heroes of our story were conceived in this oil refinery. The plastic in their bodies was formed by chemically bonding oil and gas molecules together to make monomers. In turn, these monomers were bonded into long polymer chains to make plastic in the form of millions of pellets. Those were melted at manufacturing plants and reformed in molds to create the resilient material that makes up the triplets' bodies. Machines filled the bottles with sweet bubbily liquid and they were then wrapped, shipped, bought, opened, consumed and unceremoniously discarded. And now here they lie, poised at the edge of the unknown. Bottle one, like hundreds of millions of tons of his plastic brethren, ends up in a landfill. This huge dump expands each day as more trash comes in and continues to take up space. As plastics sit there being compressed amongst layers of other junk, rainwater flows through the waste and absorbs the water-soluble compounds it contains, and some of those are highly toxic. Together, they create a harmful stew called leachate, which can move into groundwater, soil and streams, poisoning ecosystems and harming wildlife. It can take bottle one an agonizing 1,000 years to decompose. Bottle two's journey is stranger but, unfortunately, no happier. He floats on a trickle that reaches a stream, a stream that flows into a river, and a river that reaches the ocean. After months lost at sea, he's slowly drawn into a massive vortex, where trash accumulates, a place known as the Great Pacific Garbage Patch. Here the ocean's currents have trapped millions of pieces of plastic debris. This is one of five plastic-filled gyres in the world's seas. Places where the pollutants turn the water into a cloudy plastic soup. Some animals, like seabirds, get entangled in the mess. They, and others, mistake the brightly colored plastic bits for food. Plastic makes them feel full when they're not, so they starve to death and pass the toxins from the plastic up the food chain. For example, it's eaten by lanternfish, the lanternfish are eaten by squid, the squid are eaten by tuna, and the tuna are eaten by us. And most plastics don't biodegrade, which means they're destined to break down into smaller and smaller pieces called micro plastics, which might rotate in the sea eternally. But bottle three is spared the cruel purgatories of his brothers. A truck brings him to a plant where he and his companions are squeezed flat and compressed into a block. Okay, this sounds pretty bad, too, but hang in there. It gets better. The blocks are shredded into tiny pieces, which are washed and melted, so they become the raw materials that can be used again. As if by magic, bottle three is now ready to be reborn as something completely new. For this bit of plastic with such humble origins, suddenly the sky is the limit.

segments.text:
This is the story 
of three plastic bottles,
empty and discarded.
Their journeys are about to diverge

with outcomes that impact nothing less
than the fate of the planet.
But they weren't always this way.

To understand where these bottles end up,
we must first explore their origins.

The heroes of our story
were conceived in this oil refinery.
The plastic in their bodies

was formed by chemically bonding 
oil and gas molecules together
to make monomers.

In turn, these monomers were bonded
into long polymer chains to make plastic
in the form of millions of pellets.

Those were melted at manufacturing plants
and reformed in molds

to create the resilient material
that makes up the triplets' bodies.

Machines filled the bottles
with sweet bubbily liquid

and they were then wrapped, shipped,
bought, opened, consumed
and unceremoniously discarded.
And now here they lie,
poised at the edge of the unknown.

Bottle one, like hundreds of millions
of tons of his plastic brethren,
ends up in a landfill.
This huge dump expands each day

as more trash comes in
and continues to take up space.

As plastics sit there being compressed
amongst layers of other junk,
rainwater flows through the waste

and absorbs the water-soluble 
compounds it contains,
and some of those are highly toxic.

Together, they create a harmful stew
called leachate,

which can move into groundwater, 
soil and streams,
poisoning ecosystems and harming wildlife.

It can take bottle one an agonizing
1,000 years to decompose.

Bottle two's journey is stranger
but, unfortunately, no happier.

He floats on a trickle 
that reaches a stream,
a stream that flows into a river,
and a river that reaches the ocean.
After months lost at sea,

he's slowly drawn into a massive vortex,
where trash accumulates,

a place known as 
the Great Pacific Garbage Patch.

Here the ocean's currents have trapped
millions of pieces of plastic debris.

This is one of five plastic-filled
gyres in the world's seas.

Places where the pollutants
turn the water into a cloudy plastic soup.

Some animals, like seabirds, 
get entangled in the mess.

They, and others, mistake the brightly
colored plastic bits for food.

Plastic makes them feel full 
when they're not,
so they starve to death

and pass the toxins from the plastic
up the food chain.
For example, it's eaten by lanternfish,
the lanternfish are eaten by squid,
the squid are eaten by tuna,
and the tuna are eaten by us.
And most plastics don't biodegrade,

which means they're destined to break down
into smaller and smaller pieces
called micro plastics,
which might rotate in the sea eternally.

But bottle three is spared the cruel
purgatories of his brothers.
A truck brings him to a plant

where he and his companions 
are squeezed flat
and compressed into a block.

Okay, this sounds pretty bad, too,
but hang in there.
It gets better.

The blocks are shredded
into tiny pieces,
which are washed and melted,

so they become the raw materials
that can be used again.

As if by magic, bottle three
is now ready to be reborn
as something completely new.

For this bit of plastic
with such humble origins,
suddenly the sky is the limit.
